I've also got a fondant roller and some

otherwise you can use your favorite

it's a lot easier to work with and it's

cutter
I've got my giant cupcake baked and

be to make our Minnie Mouse ear shape a

little circular polka dots you can also

with that three and a half inch cutter
once again like the bow you want to do
these about twelve to twenty-four hours
in advance so they've got enough time to
set so they're going to support
themselves in your cake I've also got a
ten inch cake board and I've got mine on
a cake decorating turntable to make it a
bit easier to show you guys what I'm
doing so let's get started the first
thing you want to do is you want to take
some of that ganache now you'll notice
the different colorings in my ganache
that really dark stuff underneath is the
fresh ganache when it's still really
runny that I've used to crumb coat my
giant cupcake and then I've taken an
electric mixer waited for it to
completely
call and whipped it for about two
minutes so it kind of goes this really
nice light brown color and it becomes a
lot fluffier and a lot easier to work
with you want to take the back of your
knife and you just want to give you a
cupcake a really nice coating of that
ganache take a little bit more of that
ganache scrape it onto your cake board
this is going to make like a chocolate
glue and then you want to lift up your
whole cupcake and stick it straight on
top now at this point I don't want mine
bang in the center because I know I want
my little toy on the side so you can
move it around a little bit before that
ganache starts to set and make sure
you've got enough room for your Minnie
Mouse if you've decided to use one today
I'm pretty happy with that now you want
to just take your serrated edge knife
and you want to cut off the pointy top
of your giant cupcake this is going to
give us more of like the domed head of
Minnie Mouse take your ganache again and
just give it a little bit of a coat over
that freshly cut section and once again
I'm just making sure that I've got
ganache all the way down to the edges
and then I'm going to use the back of my
knife to just really smooth it off as
best as I can so I've got a really nice
smooth ganache surface to make your
Minnie Mouse ears you want to sprinkle
down a little bit of that cornflour but
make sure here especially when you're
working with black that you're not
getting the white corn flour on the top
of your black fondant you don't want any
little spots you can rub singular spot
there but if you get too much it
actually just makes your work look like
it's a real mess if you find that you're
getting your work a bit dirty with
cornflour just need it back together in
a big bowl and start again because you
really want to keep that piece of
fondant as black and as clean as
possible especially for your Minnie
Mouse don't roll the fondant for your is
too thin you want it to be about two
millimeters or an eighth of an inch
thick so that your ears are going to be
stable enough to be able to hold
themselves up inside your Minnie Mouse
head take your circle cutter now and you
just want to cut out from the best and
cleanest parts of your fondant two of
those beautiful nice round circles set
them aside on a piece of wax paper like
I said you want 12 to 24 hours for those
to dry so they're completely stiff and
firm here's those couple that we made
earlier you can see they're really
really firm they're not going to Bend
and they're going to stand up
beautifully in a giant cupcake take your
remaining black fondant now and you want
to roll that out as thin as you can get
it because most of the time kids don't
want a ton of fondant on top of their
cupcakes so we're just going to roll it
out get it nice and thin and you want to
be roughly the size to cover the top of
your cupcake so just pick it up drape it
over and make sure you think it's going
to cover and then take your pizza cutter
and just cut it around so
a really nice neat circle don't trim off
too much of your edges gently lay it
over the top of your ganache I love
ganache because it doesn't crust like a
buttercream wheel and then use the palm
of your hand to smooth out the tops
while you can see here I'm sort of
pulling out any little pleats I pull
them out and then I smooth them down
to stop you from getting any wrinkles
once your dome is smooth take your
finger and about a half a centimetre or
a quarter of an inch down the side of
your cupcake case you want to just push
that fondant right into the side of the
case to seal in your fondant dome take
your knife now and you just want to
gently just cut into just the fondant
and that's going to cut a little line
where you can just peel away that little
excess fondant scare you should have a
really nice neat line between your
smooth fondant dome and your cupcake
case take some of that white fondant now
and you want to roll it out really
really nice and thin and you want to
take your piping tip or a small circle
cutter and we're just going to cut out
some little white polka dots
now the stick your polka dots onto the
case it's as simple as using your

on and kind of smooth it down so that it
becomes one with the cupcake case this
is probably the most time-consuming part

opted for the pink and white version of

and white version in her dress as well
and of course you could turn this

to put your ears in you want to just

to hold them in place they're going to
go in the chocolate is going to be a

chocolate inside that little
just using my knife and you don't want

act like a glue I'm going to put it in

my mini mouth once again this is just
going to act like a glue it's going to
hold it all in place going to be
particularly sturdy for transportation
so slide that down turn it around so
that you're making sure it's a dead

Minnie Mouse's shoes is going to make
